text: Does this maybe mean that we can populate a Page based on the content of a Markdown File via API?

Very interesting question Andreas. I’m afraid I don’t have an answer for you at this time.

Theoretically though the markdown file should be accessible via a dynamically generated URL like a .js file would be. The main use-case for markdown files in your project is really to provide notes like “We’ve locked this folder because everything in it is fed by a GitHub repository.
Does markdown only work in txt files?
so <@U7SL518D6> it works similarly to gits .md files?

> Does markdown only work in txt files?
Not sure I fully understand your question. Markdown files are a type of text file.  GitHub and other tools do render special styles for the files to make them easier to view. We simply display the “code” at this time. We do syntax highlight the code and perform minor visual adjustments.

Because of the nature of markdown files being designed to be easily read with minimal markup your markdown files are readable even if they contain a lot of markdown formatting.
Because it’s a common file format when working locally your code editor can also format it. For example VS code has markdown support built-in
yeah i was wondering if the files had to have a .txt extension specifically
they need to have a `.md` extension, as that is the markdown file extension.
Is this limited to one per folder?

No. It is not a “special file” like the meta.json and fields.json files. You can place Markdown files anywhere in your projects. (except inside of a .module folder)

That said - to avoid uploading somewhat useless files you might want to locally ignore md files other than say a main one that points the person to say like a git Repo or is the main readme.md.
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/developer-reference/local-development-cli#hsignore>
Then in your repo you can still have markdown files everywhere explaining how all the pieces fit for development sake.
